\section{Introduction}

In plasma, atomic and molecular spectroscopy and especially in the study of short lived radicals it is desirable to achieve the highest possible resolution so as to resolve relevant spectroscopic features present in the spectra. This aim is usually hindered by the limited spectral resolution of the light source employed. To tackle this limitation experimentalists traditionally resort to line stabilized, high resolution light sources along with doppler free spectroscopy techniques \cite{Paul2010} or supersonic sample cooling \cite{Metcalf2012}. These techniques present, however, the inconvenience to involve relatively elaborated experimental arrangements. 

Here, we present a novel mathematical technique aimed to help experimentalists increasing the spectral resolution of their data whilst detecting real transitions hindered by the original poor resolution of their experimental data. This technique, called Super-Resolution, is based on the mathematical tools developed within the scope of Compressed Sensing (CS) \cite{CandesRombergTao06,CandesWakin2008}. 

The basic idea behind CS is that,  under the {\it a priori} knowledge that a signal or an image has a sparse representation (see below), then it can be reconstructed from far fewer data/measurements as  compared  to those required  by the well known Shannon/Nyquist sampling theory \cite{Candes06-2}. 

Here, the term sparsity means that there exist a basis in the space of functions (e.g. a Fourier basis or Wavelets) where the signal can be represented by a small number of the elements in such a basis.

In spectroscopy, a spectrum of a single element or molecule can be represented as a linear combination of single peaks of a similar shape center at specific transition wavelength values.

In this case, the spectrum can be represented by a small number of parameters, namely the locations of the peaks, their width and their amplitude. 

These parameters constitute the sparse representation in this case.\\
In a general context, Compressed Sensing can be regarded as an optimal sampling and 
interpolation algorithm for sparse signals in the appropriate base. 

Along the ideas of CS, some new versions algorithmic or computational Super-Resolution (SR) algorithms 
have been developed.  SR algorithms have  been successfully applied to many practical cases, including 
medical imaging \cite{Hayit}, satellite imaging, and video applications
(for instance sec. 1.2 in \cite{FocautRauhut2010} and  the references within). 

In this context, SR algorithms can be applied to the particular case of spectroscopy to recover high resolution features such as peak centers, from the experimental data. This kind of mathematical problem  can be treated by the recently developed mathematical theory of Super-Resolution by Cand\`es and Fernandez-Granda \cite{Candes,Candes2}.


The aim of this paper is to show that SR algorithms can  also be a valuable tool in spectral analysis 
that can help to separate peaks that cannot be separated from the original data due to instrumental 
limitations in resolution \cite{Dror,Pavel}.

In particular, we show here that the SR algorithm can dramatically 
improve the resolution of measurements, in particular allowing a 
surprising effective $70$-fold reduction in the linewidth of the spectral measurements. 

This improvement allows us to separate apart structures that are not separated 
on our original experimental data. 

To test and quantitatively show the power of the SR technique we present here 
experimental optogalvanic spectra of well known Neon and Argon transitions that 
show dramatic improvements in the resolved features after the SR post processing algorithm. 

The optogalvanic effect (OGE) is currently an active research area both in fundamental studies 
on plasma discharges as well as in technological applications. 

The OGE consist of a change in the total current of a plasma when it interact with laser light with a wavelength corresponding to an atomic or molecular transition of the gas species present in the plasma \cite{Barbieri}.

Although the specific example shown here is devoted to the OGE effect we believe SR can be applied in other types of spectroscopy, including photoionization, photoabsorption, Raman or others. 

To the best of our knowledge this is the first application of SR algorithms based on CS ideas to improving  the resolution of spectroscopic measurements.

\section{Super-Resolution algorithms}\label{Superresolution}

In any imaging system the resolution limit is measured by the shortest separation between two features, 
such as point sources, before they mingle into one. The limitations of the instrument used and, on a more 
fundamental level, the diffraction limit set the constraint to the maximum experimentally achievable resolution in optical systems. There are currently several instances  and many different approaches to SR in imaging, and we suggest the reader to revise the exciting applications of optical super-resolution (e.g.  \cite{Park2003} and references within). 
In an analogous manner as in optics, in any type of optical spectroscopy, the spectral resolution is limited 
by the linewidth of the light source and quantified by the minimum separation in wavelength required to 
set clearly apart two transitions. This has been traditionally considered the ultimate limit of 
resolution in spectroscopy.  
Since the applications of SR techniques to spectroscopy are scarce and not widespread in the experimental community, we will give a basic introduction in the context of the optogalvanic spectroscopy.

Before stating the SR algorithm in detail, we need another ingredient. In digital signal 
processing as in any digital data acquisition experiment,  there is a finite size in the 
wavelength step that is acquired, so sources and signals can be regarded both as 
discrete finite vectors $x=(a_1,\dots,a_{N})$ and $y=(y_1,\dots,y_{N})$ measured at 
fixed grid of equally spaced wavelengths $\lambda$.

In the case of continuous signals, the filter resolution is defined by $\nu_c$, 
that is the width of the low-pass filter $G$ (see Figure~\ref{fig_filter}) and is related 
to the physical properties of the experimental setting. In the experiments we also have 
another loss of resolution due to the finite size sampling in the wavelength step. Notice 
that the latter loss of resolution may change, for example, by substitution of the discrete 
to analog converting device (in this case laser's tuning device) on the experiment,  but 
this does not affect the resolution of the filter $G$. The aim of SR algorithms is to reverse 
(o deconvolve) the effect of the filter $G$ on the source signal. Once the sampling step 
size is smaller that certain threshold its effect on the algorithms is negligible.  This 
important difference, combined with the unboundedness of the $\nu_\text{hi}$  
and the separated point source nature of the source signal explain, 
why in our case, the improvement in resolution seems to be independent of the finite 
sampling step size (see Figure~\ref{fig_filter}).
